tei:msContents.tei:summary: Sema on a oval stone from Saepinum (loc. Altilia).

tei:support.tei:note: roughly oval-shaped stone, similar to the support of ItAnt Oscan 269

tei:layout.tei:note: the inscription follows the curve of the stone in continuous text and the ends of lines 3 and 4 are on the reverse of the stone.

tei:handNote.tei:note: Letters are in relief, a double dot is used as punctuation sign.

tei:origin.tei:origDate: middle of the 2nd century BC - beginning of the 1st century BC

tei:encodingDesc.tei:p: Marked-up according to the EpiDoc Guidelines

tei:div.tei:p: Chi (sei) tu? Io (sono) una pietra. Di chi? Di Beto Adio figlio di Aufino

tei:desc.tei:ref: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International license â€“ (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0).

tei:div.tei:p: Who (are) you? I (am) a stone. Whose (are you)? (I belong) to [lit. I am of] Baetus Adius son of Aufinus

tei:desc.tei:ref: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 license.

tei:note.tei:p: The inscription was originally part of the Collezione Santangelo (Naples), which was acquired by the archaeological museum of Naples between 1863 and 1875. In the the late 19th century the inscription was apparently lost (see Kent 1913: 196). Fortunately the stone was found at the end of the 1970s (see Prosdocimi 1978: 844).
One side of the stone is very abraded and difficult to read.
The interpretation of the text and the exact function of the stone are been a long time debated.
The text is constructed as a dialogue between the stone and a hypothetical reader. The stone becomes a "speaking object" declaring its beloloning to baÃ­teÃ­s aadiieÃ­s avfineÃ­s.

Following the most recent and now shared interpretation, the stone is a sema identifying the membership of the deceased to an esoteric circle. This interpretation is due to Poccetti 1994 (see also Poccetti 2000 and Crawford, ImIt 2011: 1132).

Contra, Buck 1928(2), Ribezzo 1914, Sommers 1920, Friedrich 1917, Bonfante 1935 , Pisani 1953 and Bottiglioni 1954 assuming the stone was a sling-shot bullet (glans). In any case, the general interpretation of the text provided by these scholars is different. Sling-shot bullets often show satirical inscriptions and our dialogue could be interpreted as addressed to the person the bullet would hit. However, the stone is bigger than a normal glans. Furthermore, it was inscribed using the technique of exciso in relief, too sophisticated for such use.

Vetter 1953, followed by Haas 1969 and Pisani 1974: 114, proposed the identification of the stone as a stone marking a grave), like the "ciottoloni" used in the Venetic area. However our stone is smaller. The general interpretation of the text provided by these scholars is different.
More recentely, Maggiani 1986 and Rix 2002: 86 assumed that the stone was a sors (lot), used in the context of divination practices (lithomancy).
